support.p: This is a stone (possibly limestone or marble) gravestone ( 38 cm 88 cm 8 cm ).

supportDesc.condition: Very good condition, all the text is visible and legible, as well as the detailed decoration

layoutDesc.layout: The text is carved onto the gravestone and is centred on the second quarter from the top. There is no border and the gravestone itself has a simple rectangle shape with a rounded top.

handDesc.summary: The text varies in size, with the largest letters used for the names.

decoDesc.decoNote: There are two pieces of decoration here other than the text. First, above the text, is the emblem of the Royal Army Service Corps, of which Driver Gibbs was a art. Second, below the text, filling much of the space between the text and the ground is a crucifix.

div.p: T/277540 Driver F. J. Gibbs, Royal Army Service Corps. 7th January 1919, age 27.Sacred to the memory of James Jarvis of this parish, baker. Died May the 18th 1826, aged 58 years.

This twentieth century gravestone lists the name of one occupant, F. J. Gibbs. We can learn his full name, Frederick John Gibbs, from the fact that this grave is managed by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission (https://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/343723/gibbs,-frederick-john/), along with three other graves in this churchyard, however we do not know were he died, as it was also after the end of World War I. From the age and the date of death, we can calculate that Frederick Gibbs was born c. 1892. The date of death is also interesting as he was a serviceman who died after the end of World War I. This grave is located next to the lych gate (the main entrance to the churchyard), a prominent position normally reserved for clergy or members of the church staff.
